values:
I've been pretty emotional and aware of God's voice this Christmas season. It's...interesting. Lately, for most of this semester I should say, I've felt a bit distant from God. I knew He was there, I knew He was taking care of me, but I was not listening as well as usual to Him and my relationship with Him was suffering. Until about a week or so ago.

Let me give a little background on what happened. One of my dearest friends lost her baby last week. The funeral is tomorrow, and I would appreciate your prayers for her and her husband if you think about it. I've come to realize that God has created me as an incredibly empathetic person. If someone else is hurting, I take that hurt upon myself and do what I can to care for and ease the other person's pain. Facing this loss was harder for me, I think, than many other things I've had to face in my life. I couldn't fix it. I didn't know what to say. All I could do was love. All I can do is love. The other thing I've come to realize is that because I care well for people, because I do my best to love them no matter what, people trust me and are comfortable with me. I make friends easily, which is a new thing for me. I never used to be comfortable with myself and with making friends. Now, every person I meet is a prospective friend, and God has brought some incredible people into my life this way. I am so thankful that God has created me the way that I am, and that He has healed my brokenness when it comes to friendships and trust issues...He had made me clean, pure, and innocent again...but I digress...

I got choked up several times while we were singing at church this Sunday. I really, really enjoy my home church's new pastor, and I believe that God is going to use her in amazing ways to grow New Salem Presbyterian church. She preached yesterday on how NSPC needs to be pregnant with LOVE. And how they need to do everything out of love and nothing else...and then God will bring opportunities to minister to the church. At the evening service, she quoted on of my favorite Scripture passages:

    In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. He was with   God in the beginning. Through him all things were made; without him nothing was made that has been made. In him was life, and that life was the light of men. The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it. John 1:1-5.

The light of the world is Jesus. Jesus saves, Jesus extinguishes the darkness, Jesus heals the broken, and Jesus brings saving Grace. I love Him, and my heart breaks everytime someone I know hasn't experienced His love. I think this Christmas season my focus has been returned to Jesus. I rest in His love, because His love comes from God. I have the ability to love others only because the love that I feel from God is overflowing from my heart. I CANNOT do it alone. Let me close with a small prayer, a combination of a few of my favorite Christmas hymns.

O, come, O, come, Emmanuel, and ransom captive Israel. Come, Son of God, love's pure light. Let the radiant beams from thy Holy face illumine our lives so we can see the dawn of thy redeeming grace. Thank you, Lord Jesus, Loving God Incarnate, for coming to as a babe to save us. Be near us and stay close beside us in this coming year, and let us fix our eyes on you, and you alone, the author and perfector of our faith. Amen and Amen.

The semester, that is. And I can scarcely believe it. It's a little crazy, all that God has done in my life in the past few months. I invite you to join me on a journey of relflection on the God's goodness, God's provision, God's steadfastness, and His many other characteristics. Where to start?

Before I get into what God has been doing, I want to ask for some prayer. A good friend of mine, who has truly been a blessing from God to me this semester, lost her baby this week. It has been rough. I am finding more and more that God has broken my heart for others who are hurting, and sometimes it makes life difficult for me too. Please pray that I would have the strength, the love, and the encouragement to care for this friend, even as I am at home for Christmas. Please pray for her and her husband as well, because this was their first baby and they have been trying for a while to concieve. It's particularly hard at this time of the year. I won't divulge their names on the internet, but please just pray. Thanks. Enough sad stuff...on to good things!

I was nervous beginning this semester. I was worried that no-one would come to SWAT, that I wouldn't get along with my new on-campus supervisor, and that working with my new area director would be difficult. I worried about support raising and asking people for money. I stressed out over my leadership team, and I stressed even more about things I did or did not do. But, let me just tell you a little bit about how God has worked through these things.

God has been incredibly faithful in bringing amazing students to SWAT. This group may be smaller, and I may be taking fewer students to Jubilee this year, but it doesn't matter. They are willing to stretch themselves, and they are willing to be vulnerable in a group. But not only did God bring students to SWAT. He brought students into my life who wanted to attend church as well. I have taken at least two students to Pond Bank each week this semester. But God didn't see fit to stop there, even! He brought Angelika into my life. She is a deaf student who really wanted to go to a church that had an interpreter. It just so happens that a friend of mine from Pond Bank is an interpreter and pulled her connections to get me into a sign language class, as well as to get an interpreter there and paid for anytime Angelika wants to go to church. It's amazing the way God works.

Kim, my new on-campus supervisor, is not just an AWESOME boss, but also has become a great friend. I really like the way she thinks, and we definitely work well together. God brings everyone into my life for a reason, and professional development is definitely part of the reason Kim is there for me. She cares about me as a person, as well as professionally. She holds me to a higher standard. It's nice. And she's on my side and will help me out with anything I need, and will let me know if I do something wrong.

The same goes for my new CCO area director (that's CCO lingo for boss). Charity is also awesome. She and I are pretty similar, so she has be pegged pretty well. She can usually figure out what I am thinking and how I will react to certain things. It's nice. Granted, it's tough sometimes to have a boss who holds you accoutable to the things that you are supposed to be doing, as well as challenges you to go a step beyond that. But, I would rather have an involved, caring, questions-asking AD than one who is hands-off. I praise God for working things out to allow Charity to be my boss.

Support raising. Need I say more? Believe it or not, this is not my favorite part of the job. But, God provides. Jehovah-Jireh. So true. I worked my butt off over the summer and at the beginning of the semester trying to get my level of support up. At this time last year, I was barely, and I mean barely, making it. I was hardly at 30% of what my paycheck should have been. After a lot of prayer and prodding, I put the pedal to the metal and worked hard to figure out what being faithful in support raising actually looked like for me. For me, it's about relationships. I couldn't ask for better churches than the ones that take care of me in Franklin County. Pond Bank and Salem just to name two. It's not just about the money. I have found friends and community, and I am thankful for that. I am living in one of the church member's houses for the next three months to save money, as well as she is my support raising accountability partner. She rocks. I am proud to say that right now, thanks to God, Wendy, and lots of hard work, I am at about 50-60% of where I should be support-wise. I have a long way to go, but God is faithful and I am trying.

There are still more areas of my life where God has been faithful and good when I haven't been. He loves me and cares for me more than I deserve. I have been so selfish this past semester, and I haven't spent enough time with Him. Be looking for more reflections in the next few days. I am actually taking some time off over the Christmas holiday to process my semester and to see what I can do better in the future. Please pray for me as I go through this process. And have a wonderful and Blessed Christmas! I love you all! *hug*

Have you ever felt like you were just stuck? Like you couldn't pray, didn't want to pray, couldn't focus to pray, and guilty over it all? I am a campus minister with the Coalition for Christian Outreach. I put up a pretty good front sometimes, but I definitely don't always have it together. But I've found that it is in those moments of weakness, of feeling stuck, God finds ways to speak to me and to restore my soul.

It's funny the way God works. I read blogs pretty regularly...and oftentimes they are how I connect with God. I have a hard time focusing on writing in my own journal or on my own blog about different Biblical passages and whatnot, so I turn to others. It's nice to have my beliefs reinforced by something else I read. Anyway...recently I read one blog and one article at http://www.relevantmag.com that helped me see God a little more clearly.

In the first, an article that you can read at http://www.thelongbrake.com, the writer reflected on renewal. I've been in some serious need of attitude re-vamping lately, as evidenced in my often crappy mood. When I am not "plugged into the vine" very well, I get tired and cranky. In the post previously mentioned, the author states two things that struck me. Here's the first:

    "you are who you are because of the things you've gone through. God has taken you through some very specific things, both big and small, to shape you into who He wants you to be. it's true. it's not always easy, but it's true."

Can you say, Wow? I had a bit of a tiff with one of my dearest friends on Tuesday night. But she is a new friend; I've only been spending time with her since about August. She doesn't know the back story to my life. She doesn't know the dark places in my soul where I struggle. It's a challenge for me to go there and share why certain things upset me and why I react the way I do to certain things. I can't blame her for wondering why I was upset when I've never shown her certain sides of me. It's in those moments that I remember. I remember how God has molded me and shaped me into who I am NOW. The old has passed away; the new has come. I am a different person than I was years ago. I hate it when old issues rear their head, but it's then that I go back to God, and He heals me and renews me again. Amen and Amen.

This is how the aforementioned writer closes his post, and I can't echo it more wholeheartedly:

    "i have come to believe that God is a God of restoration. of redemption. of rescue.

    i believe that God wants to restore you. me. i don't claim to have all of the answers, nor do i claim to understand God very well, if at all. but i do know that rescue is central to who He is.

    so i hope that you, friend, will be restored today. i hope that you will be rescued and gain a more full understanding that God loves you. your past. your present. your pains. your failings and victories. all of it.

    all of it.

    you are who you are because He formed you this way. and He wants you to be who you will be under his rescuing and redemptive hand.

    and as i live, i keep hearing Him say come back. i love you. i want you for who you are. come back. keeping coming back."

God is my rescuer, my redeemer, my healer. And I can't thank Him enough for that on a day to to day basis. Even when I am in a funk, even when I feel like I'm lost and can't pray, He's still there to pick me up off of my face.

The other article from Relevantmag.com titled "Wading in the Worry" ends on this note:

    "Next time every decision in your life seems to be staring you straight in the face and everything you have so carefully constructed seems to be collapsing, remember the futility of worrying. Instead of lending yourself to despair and anxiety and trying to add days onto your life, please take a chance to remember the timing and sovereignty of God and allow Him to provide you with comfort.

    He has and will provide you with everything that you need; be content to rest in His arms and accept His peace because it might just change your life."

Amen and Amen. I worry too much somtimes about how badly I've failed in certain aspects of my job, or even what people think of me because of the job that I do. I have to surrender these thoughts to God. He will take them from me and heal me and show me that my real value lies in Him and in Him alone. It's "the timing and sovereignty of God" that I have to remember on a day to day basis. He's in charge; not me. He knows what I will do with the rest of my life. He knows who I'll marry, He knows where I'll live out my days, He knows what jobs I'll do. I don't need to worry because He's got a plan, and He's in control. I take comfort in that. When I take the time to lean on Him and to rest in His arms, I am refreshed. And my soul is restored. I just have to remember to go to Him in these times.

Hi folks! Sorry it's been so long since I've updated...my life is a whirlwind of activity these days, and my internet access is limited. I've also had a bit of writer's block...so much has been going on that it's been hard for me to even put words to what I'm feeling! It's craziness...but God is steadfast in the midst of these things.

So, where to start? I guess I can start by telling you all that I have been incredibly challenged lately. I have several students that keep me hopping all the time, as well as I have been struggling with some stuff of my own. It's so hard to be faithful sometimes! It's especially hard when you are alone on a campus, and running the ministry on your own. I have to make some really hard decisions, and I definitely can't do everything. I am beginning to realize why Jesus sent the disciples out two by two. I don't have all the answers, and I can't provide them for every student. Not that I didn't know this before, but sometimes it's just a slap in the face reminder.

And, how the heck do you deal with coworkers who hate working where they do? I love Mont Alto, and I love my students. I understand that they are not all at a level where they are ready to do certain things, like give up their spring break for a service project. What do you do when your coworker insinuates that all Christians should be doing service and should understand the concept? I tried to explain that my students are doing all that they can do and are ready to do right now, but this person just didn't want to hear it. It makes for my job to be a little difficult when there are those who make me feel like I'm not doing it well. Anyway...

On the bright side of things, campus gave me $2100 to take students to Jubilee, and I think we have a church volunteering a bus to drive us out. It's exciting!

And I've been having some good friend time lately. It's awesome when you can connect with someone else in the ministry who is having similar struggles to yours. It is always good to be able to talk through things with someone who understands!

Another exciting thing is that Pond Bank is providing a regular interpreter for my deaf student on Sunday mornings. I am really thankful for this amazing community of people, and I couldn't imagine leaving them right now.

And God sure does like to convict us. Last Sunday, Pastor Lin preached on the "Honor your father and your mother" commandment. Imagine that. The Sunday that I am angry with my folks for not coming out to visit, she preaches on how hard it is for us to understand our parents and respect them even if they aren't always great. Wow. Thanks God. It's so hard to be in my position sometimes. Mainly due to the fact that I know I am pleasing God, but displeasing my parents and many other folks from home by not using my college degree and making the big bucks. It's hard to not fit into the mold. But I try my hardest to let that go. God is in control, and I am doing what He has called me to do. I have taken up my cross and followed Him, and that's all that matters. On that note, I need to go do some more support raising stuff. Good day, all!

Today is the 5-yr anniversary of 9/11.  I think sometimes we so easily forget about all the people who lost their lives that day trying to save others, or simply by showing up for work.  I was just thinking the other day about how I really don't face any danger when I go to work every day.  Yes, it is a spiritual battleground...but I am not generally in any physical danger.  There are people who risk their lives every day to share the Love of Christ.  I don't consider myself to be one of those...sometimes I feel like my job is play.  Sometimes I think people misunderstand my job is a real job.  I hate it when people ask me, "so, is this a shorttime gig, a bridge job, or do you plan on doing it forever?" Depending on the circumstances, oftentimes I just tell them that it's up to God what I do two years from now when my CCO contract is up.  But that's not always the answer that is appropriate.  It drives me nuts...

What also got me thinking today was an interaction with one of my coworkers as well as a conversation with my area director.  Not everyone I work with is going to extend grace to me.  Some people just really aren't going to like me.  Some people just really aren't going to be nice.  And that's when I have to extend the love of Christ the most.  That's when I have to be patient and keep my mouth shut.  That's when I have to walk away when I'm upset.  But it's so hard sometimes!  Those old habits die hard.  At least being snappy is not necessarily in my nature.  I don't know how to respond when people are mean to me.  It's tough.

But then I began to put things into perspective.  I have friends here who love me, both on campus and off.  Julie bought me chocolate and dinner today.  Even though it's dreary outside, I can be happy because I know Jesus.  No matter how tired I get, or how hard of a day I am having, when I fix my eyes on Jesus, the author and perfector of my faith, it'll be okay.  Jesus never said we signed up for something easy by following Him, and I have to continually remind myself of that.  Not to say that that is easy...but when I remain positive, remain in prayer, and remain focused on Christ, I'm a much happier person.  And that's it for now.

Wow. The first week of classes is over as of the end of today. It's been a rollercoaster couple of weeks for me. If you were to ask me what I have done these past two weeks...I don't know that I could necessarily tell you. Sometimes it's really a hard thing to explain...but yesterday my landlord described it pretty accurately by stating that I "just spend a lot of time with people." That's pretty much the explanation of my job...I help people to feel comfortable with me and to trust me, and then hopefully it will come to the point where I can share the gospel with them. Even if I never do, the ground has been laid. The foundations for friendship and for trust of other Christians in the future has been created. It's hard sometimes to know that I won't always see the results of my labor, but I still love my job. I honestly wouldn't be doing anything else right now.

Yesterday was really cool. I have a deaf student named Angelika this year, and she is a Christian. She desperately wants to go to church, but PSU won't pay for a translator for personal use. Therefore, God bless her, my friend Lisa from Pond Bank came over yesterday and met with Angelika. Lisa's been signing off and on for about 30 years, so she and Angelika had a pretty good conversation...and then after Lisa left, Angelika and I proceeded to have a good conversation (via paper and pencil, mind you) as well. It was really awesome. She's got a cool story, and I really look forward to getting to know her better. She is going to Pond Bank with me on Sunday...Lisa is trying to find someone to interpret for her. But I think she'll like it whether we have an interpreter or not. The people are so wonderful and caring there...I wish I could get more students to go with me. I may have a few going this Sunday...we shall see. Things seem to be pretty hit or miss around here lately.

For example, I had 23 students at chapel Sunday morning and 36 students sign up for SWAT on the list at the involvement fair. But how many actually showed up at SWAT last night? Only about 15 or 20. It was weird. I was even missing a quarter of my leadership team. Maybe it's my fault for not communicating well with them...maybe it's my fault for not advertising SWAT better...however, I was pretty disappointed in some of my leaders last night. It may be a rough year ahead. We shall see! But I'm trying to look on the bright side....if I have reached ONE SINGLE student in my time here, than I have been successful. If I have helped one student step outside of his or her comfort zone and question something, than I have been successful. But it's hard sometimes...I guess I shouldn't set expectations.

I'm excited for Sunday this week. I am playing at Salem, picking some students up to go to Pond Bank, and then heading out to a crab feed with Lin after church. Really excited about that...she's paying for me...all the crabs, chicken, and sides you can eat, and all the beer, soda, and iced tea you can drink. It's to benefit the local retirement home for nuns. Nothing like tossing one back with the local Catholics and having some good conversations! Super excited about it...

Oh well...I'm gonna sign off for now...my area director is coming at 2, and I have some stuff to contemplate and to do before she shows up. I hope the community board meeting goes well tonight! Take care all, and talk to you soon!

So, I've been pondering again. It's a dangerous passtime. I've been reading the Sisterchicks series of books these past few days. And don't you dare laugh at me. All of us need our releases, and mine just happens to be cheesy, girly, feel-good novels. I know they are super cheesy...but I love them! But anyway...I've been reading these books and realizing how grateful I am for the girlfriends I have.

I was pretty lonely all last year out here in the middle of nowhere...I missed my sorority sisters and the community I had with them. I missed late night donut runs and girly movies. I missed having someone to hold me when I was crying and comfort me when I was upset. But God is good. It took me a year to really realize how important my girls are. 

Today especially I realized that I am going to make it. A newfound girlfriend of mine from here shared with me that she has FINALLY gotten pregnant. I know she's not sharing that with everyone because it's still early. I am truly blessed to be a part of her life. I don't care what age my "sisterchicks" are...they are important to me! There's this friend, who is about 28, and then there's my pastor friend who is pushing 50...they both represent different things in my life, and I wouldn't be the same without them. It took a while, but when I was open and allowed myself to be known, the friendships came. Now I have to learn how to make time for them again.

Anyway...here's a shout-out to all my girls...even if we don't talk all the time...you have blessed me in some way...and I am glad to know you. I know that if I ever needed anything...I could turn to any of you and in an instant you'd be by my side if you could. Thanks for all you have been and are to me! I love you! God truly created us to be relational creatures, and for that, I am truly thankful. Amen and Amen.

Well all, it's that wonderful time of year again when my students return. Except this year, I know what to expect. Sort of. There are so many things I should have done last year or this summer, and so many things I shouldn't have done. All I can do is continue to live daily in the light of God's grace and let go of my mistakes. All I can do is be weak and allow Him to be strong and to work out His purpose through me.

While I was at Roxbury recently, one of my favorite pastors used one of my new favorite "Christian-ese" phrases. He said that we all need to be "Jesus with SKIN-ON" and that we need to find people who for us are "Jesus with Skin-on". Hm. Since he used this phrase, I've been trying to figure out what the heck that means for me. How can I be the hands and feet of Christ in my humanness? In my sinful, weak, fallen state? How can I NOT let the things of this world get in my way when I am trying to care for my students and bring them nearer to their Lord and Savior? How can I not let the "Red tape" of PSU get in my way? I may not always do things to the best of my ability...and that is not glorifying to God. So how do I deal with it? I let it go when I mess up, let Him take charge, and do better next time. It's taken me a while to learn how to do this. And it's still hard.

It's hard for me as well to balance. It will be different this year because I know the campus folk. I just don't know lots of students yet. How can I get my energy back that I need? Prayer. Rest. Friends. But how do I balance these things? We're still working this one out.

I've also been pondering what it means to walk what I talk. I do to a point, but then there comes the point when I get tired of walking the walk. But I CAN'T....CAN'T give up pursuing the goodness of God. When I focus on Jesus 100% all the time....I can make it. I need to stay focused on Jesus...not on money, not on movies, not on who my future husband will be, not on friends...ON JESUS. Then I can make it and be happy. It's hard...and it goes against all the world has to say...but I have to do it. I am called to do it. I can't be like Peter and take my eyes of Jesus and sink. Yes, we all screw up. But the more I screw up, the further from Jesus I become. And I DON'T like being far away from Jesus. So yeah. That's where I'm at right now. Please pray for my energy levels and my passion as my students return...I was reading my friend Byron's page today...he is so passionate about what he does. He loves his books, and even though he doesn't regularly have students, he loves them as well. He pursues the best at all times. I aspire to be like him. I need to find my passion. I dabble in passions right now. I love Mont Alto. I love my students. But I don't want to support raise for the rest of my life. What are my dreams? What are my aspirations? I am not sure. God is directing my life right now. But what does that mean for the rest of my life? What am I going to do when my three years with CCO are up? Grad school? Teaching? Seminary? What? I'm not too good at saving money right now...or at preparing for the future. So, right now I'm resting in God's grace. That's all I can do. Trust that God is in control...and that it will all work out. Thanks for reading my rambling, and talk to you all soon! ;-)

So, I've been a very busy girl lately...I led worship Sunday at Salem, went to church at Pond Bank, and then spent the afternoon and part of the evening at Roxbury.  I have been at Roxbury for at least one service a day since Saturday, except for last night.  But God has been good.  In short, I was really having a rough day on Sunday, and God provided a message through the speaker directly to me.  I love it when that happens!  I had a pastor friend and his wife and another woman pray for me, and things have been pretty good since.  There have been some resolutions in the relationship I've been struggling with lately, and God has really given me a peace in that area.

Last night was a huge blessing as well.  Monday morning, after praying Sunday night that I would figure out what it means to have friends and not be lonely out here in Mont Alto, a girl from church gave me a call.  She is really cool, but I would never have expected her to just call me and invite me over to have dinner and hang out.  She's a blessing.  We ate at 5:30, and I ended up leaving around 10.  God is good.  We had good "girlie" conversation, ate some cobbler, and LAUGHED!  We had some serious convo in there too...it was a great mixture.  God definitely is good!

But I do have one prayer request...and this seems to be a recurring one.  Please pray that I figure out this housing thing...I like where I'm living...but it's hard sometimes because it's someone else's house.  She really couldn't ask for a better tenant...I have been courteous, clean, and not had a drinking binge parties.  Imagine that!  But she's pretty nit-picky at times...so please pray that I can figure out why God put me here...I know there's a reason...just not sure what.  Please pray as well that if this is not where I'm supposed to be, God would work things out, and that I would trust Him in the situation no matter what.  That not trusting Him thing...it might be why I ended up where I am now.  We shall see what happens!

Anyway...thanks for reading, devoted friends, and have a great day! I'm off to Roxbury with Jodi for Missions day! WoOt!

You know there's something wrong when it's not even 10 o'clock in the morning and you can SEE the air...yicky humidity. I like the fall, when there are cool breezes and pretty trees. This humidity and heat is fine if you have air conditioning, a swimming pool, or absolutely nothing to do. It stinks for animals and for the elderly and for the young. It's definitely not fun for those who work outside. I prayer walked my campus last night, and it wasn't even that hot. But because of the humidity, I was covered in sweat and nastiness. I said a quick prayer for the kids who are attending band camp on Mont Alto's campus this week...we definitely don't need anyone to die of heatstroke. All I can do is pray that they are taking adequate breaks and drinking lots of water.

Anyway...life has been pretty good lately. Shawn and I have been hanging out more than usual, and it's been really fun. He definitely keeps me accountable to taking time off and to doing my job well! I also got my new computer last Friday. God is super awesome in how He provides for us! A man from one of the churches I attend donated me a brand new acer travelmate 2420 with microsoft office for FREE! Absolutely free. God is good. I thank and praise Him daily for all He does for me, even when I don't deserve it!

One sad note, though. Please continue praying for my friend Georg and his family. His initial surgery to remove the tumor went well, but since then he has had swelling on the brain that the doctors are having a tough time controlling. Then today they found out that he has blood clots in his lungs, which means that he is back in ICU. He can't take blood thinners to fix the problem because it would cause him to bleed on the brain again. So please be praying for him. He is an amazing man of God, and I have been blessed to know him.

I'll be heading out here shortly to let the dog out for my landlord, and then I'm going to a concert in Shippensburg with Shawn. Good times! The only problem is, it's stinkin' hot! Drink lots of water, friends, and stay cool if possible! Take care all!

Hi folks.  Last week was awesome.  I drove up to Ocean City, NJ to visit one of my students who is taking part in the Ocean City Beach Project.  She's having a blast, and I really think she is benefitting from this summer.  WoOt!  It was really good for me to go up and chat with her and care for her and care for my other friends who are staffing the beach project, as well as meet new students and have other good conversations with them.  It was especially a large blessing to be able to be there while Byron Borger of Hearts and Minds Bookstore was the week's speaker.  He talked about faithfulness in all areas of life, and a wholistic, all of life redeemed perspective on the Gospel.  It was wonderful, as usual!  I purchased "The Fabric of Faithfulness" and "Velvet Elvis".  Velvet Elvis is such a good book! I bought the audio version and listened to it on my drive back from the beach, and then again on my drive home for my sister's party.  I am really looking forward to "Fabric" because I really enjoyed Mr. Garber when he spoke at Staff Sem.  We shall see!  I would definitely recommened both books to anyone who cares about faith stuff at all...both are different kinds of books with similiar purposes...sustaining the church and glorfying God.

Right before I left I got to catch up with one of my best friends from college. Crutches are an interesting invention. As some of you might know, I am a pretty accident prone person. However, I had only been on crutches once or twice in my life for some simple sprains. Until March 24. After a good morning of the last T-teams at Messiah college, a friend and I decided we would go to 10,000 villages to check the place out. I'd been there before, but she had never been, so it was a good experience. I bought a ring and we had a good ole' time looking around at the various world items. But little did I know that when we went to leave I would be in for an adventure.

You see, the curb at 10,000 villages is quite high and I have tripped over it before. But usually, I can catch myself. This time was different. I fell off the curb, ripped the left knee of my jeans and severly sprained my right ankle. No driving for me for a while! I was sure that I had broken it. I rode with my friend back to Messiah and we had two of our wilderness folks look at my ankle. No decision was made as to whether or not it was broken then, but it was very swollen and nasty looking. The verdict of the wilderness guys was that it was too swollen to be xrayed at the moment, and not severe enough for me to bother sitting in the crazy ER on a Friday night. So, I called a friend from church, we drove to her house, I sacked out on her couch for the night, and she drove me to the ER the next morning. Good times. Crutches for a month. Hooray.

But I digress. I ended up taking last week off from work, since I couldn't be on my stupid foot for more than 2 hours without it swelling to about 3-4 times its normal size. But God taught me a lot in that one week. It's funny, because we had had an annoiting service at church the week before where I had asked God to anoint me with better rest and sleep. Little did we know that He was going to use an injury in order to get my attention and slow me down!

I have been humbled a great deal by this experience. I am a very independent person, and I like my time alone. But usually, that time alone is spent away from my apartment. Since I can't drive, I was stuck at home or stuck asking for someone to take me to where I needed to go. I am truly blessed to have the friends that I do here. God has brought some awesome people into my life, and I know I'll never be the same because of them. Several of my friends have been hauling my butt everywhere from work to church to Walmart to out for food. Not that I wouldn't do the same for them, but it has taken a lot for me to accept the kindness and not become irritable and bitter because of my weakness. God is good. I think overall this injury was meant to teach me to rely more on my peers and my friends and on Him. I'm still learning and processing, and I am still really stubborn, but I still praise God for my busted ankle! Thanks for reading my musings!

Hi friends! My life has been sheer insanity for the past month.  But it's been good insanity, not bad insanity.  Jubilee took place the weekend of February 24-26, 2006.  What an awesome experience!  I can't even begin to tell you how good of a time my students had, and how much some of the speakers impacted their lives.  They are all glad that I made them go, kicking and screaming. ;)  Tony Campolo rocked their worlds, and the Holy Spirit was definitely moving through our fellowship the two weeks prior to Jubilee.  Everything tied together.  It is amazing the way God works sometimes, when we turn things over to Him!  I have to continually remind myself of such things.  Anyway, Jubilee was awesome.

The Friday morning before we left for Jubilee, I got an desperate email from one of my coworkers looking for drivers for his Spring break trip to Mississippi.  As luck would have it, my spring break intersected with theirs, and I was able to go.  I hadn't had any plans since my students were going to Myrtle beach, so I jumped on board the Tylertown, MS trip.  What an amazing experience.  I can't even begin to describe to you the way God works through other people.  We rebuilt the whole back end of a house and did lots of painting.  But in the process, we were building relationships as well.  We worked with a crew from IN, and it was awesome to see how much work the students with whom I went could get done alongside these skilled workers.  God is good.  The families were very appreciative of all of our work, and I hope to return sometime in the future. 

On Friday, the last day of the trip, we were able to go to New Orleans.  Since I went through staff training with an amazing, faith-filled, joy filled woman from New Orleans, I thought I'd call her up and ask her what we should see while we were there.  Little did I know that this would be the reason I was present on this trip.  My friend told us that if we wanted to see the New Orleans that was, we should go to the French Quarter.  Then, she said that if we wanted to see true destruction and what Hurricane Katrina really did, not what we had seen on TV, she would give us street by street directions to get there.  This was her home.  She told us how to get directly from Canal Street in the city to the Ninth Ward.  The Ninth Ward is the section of the city hit worst by the storm, and it is where my friend lived.  She is now in Philadelpia working for the CCO, and her family is living outside the city with some other relatives.  The devastation was overwhelming, and I really was profoundly affected by it.  Upon crossing the bridge into the ninth ward, the guy who was leading the trip and all the students in my van gasped.  There were "Oh my goodnesses" and other such responses.  And once we got down into the area and up close, things were even harder to digest.  Had it not been for my connection with my friend during training, I would not have been able to take these students to see this horrific sight.  Had I not been on this trip, they would have missed seeing the true damage and left feeling like LA was okay. 

There is much to be done.  I can only hope that by seeing the Ninth Ward, the students I was with were impacted to bring change.  I hope that they go home and share what they learned, and what they saw, and challenge the rest of us to not forget New Orleans.  It is not all fixed.  It is not all better.  There are still many folks who need aid, and the city will probably never be the same.  I am thankful to God for the way He used this trip to open my eyes to my lack of knowledge about many things.  I am also thankful for the connections and bonds that were formed on this trip.  The friends I made will be friends for a long time, and I am sure I will use my fellow CCO staff member as a resource in the future.  It was awesome to watch him work with his students all week, and also to hear the behind the scenes facts that his wife shared with me.  Praise God for a really, really good Spring break!

That's about all I have for now, friends.  I am still processing quite a few things, and I will be picking up my pictures today.  Please pray for me as I begin debriefing my students after Jubilee, and sharing their experiences with local congregations.  Also pray that I can share my MS and LA experience with them in a way that will change their thinking about what they possess.  Many blessings to you!

So, apparently being an oddball is a continuing theme in my life...let me explain. This is probably going to be a long post again...here goes!

Upon returning to school, my home group studied Numbers 13 and 14...you know, 10 were bad, 2 were good? Automatically, the passage brought to mind for me how hard it must have been for Caleb and Joshua to serve God and to go against the masses. They were oddballs in their faith. They knew God personally, saw Him in their lives, and heard Him speak. While the masses were threatening to stone them and find new leaders, Joshua and Caleb tore their clothes in despair over the lack of faith of their nation. But here's the clincher: not only did my homegroup study this passage, but Marlin also preached on it on Sunday. I asked him about it afterwards, and he said he had planned the sermon before he had read the home group passage. So here are some of the insights and good quotes that I gained from Marlin's sermon.

The first point he made was in regards to our point of view. He asked us, "What do you see for 2006? A cluster of grapes or a pack of giants?". Now let me clarify. If you are familiar with Numbers, you know that 12 men from the tribes went to investigate the promised land. They found that it was indeed "flowing with milk and honey"; however, there were also giants there...descendants of Anak...the men, other than Joshua and Caleb, said that they were like "grasshoppers in the eyes of these giants." Now, what was so different about Caleb and Joshua that they would look on the bright side instead of the dark side? They had faith. They believed their God would deliver them into the promised land, no matter who He had to defeat along the way. So, here's the insight I gained. I need to change my point of view for 2006. I do have a tendency to be a pessimist...and it's not healthy. When I am pessimist, I choose to be intimidated by Satan. I CHOOSE NOT TO BE A GRASSHOPPER! My God can do anything, and I need to remember that more frequently. I will not allow support raising and other difficult circumstances to overcome me, but I will pray and allow God to take control of the situation. GOD CAN DO IT!

Here's another insight...Marlin told this story about a little boy trying to get a big rock out of his sandbox. He has exhausted his resources, and not succeeded. Suddenly he sees a shadow. It is his father. He explains the situation to dear old dad, telling him that he has done all that he could. Dad proceeds to tell his son that he did not do all that he could; he didn't ask his Father for help. So, what I take away from that is that I need to not be prideful in asking for help, whether that be from my Heavenly Father or from the people around me. It's so hard sometimes to see where I need help, and when I should ask for it. So that's something I am going to work on this year...and I know that my FATHER, MY GOD, will help me in my time of need if I ask.

I need to spend more time in prayer this semester/year/in general...I feel so much better when my prayer life is healthy. It's tough when I am not praying enough! Another insight Marlin offered was that of the Bumblebee. According to him, Honeybees defy physics. If a bumblebee were to obey physics, it would not be able to fly. It's wings would not be able to bear the weight of it's body and food. But somehow, the bee manages to fly, and quickly at that. God knows how it works, even though we don't. I need to fly with God and let Him handle things instead of trying to do it all on my own.

I hate the word pessimism. One author defined a pessimist as "someone who complains about the noise when opportunity knocks." I need to not be like this. I need to rise to the challenge and run from the attitude that I can't do things. God is in control. It'll be okay. I also need to remember that "if there is no risk, then there is no growth." My day to day life is a big risk...but I still play it safe on lots of things. What would it mean for me to just spread my wings and do stuff...whether it fails or succeeds? It's hard for me, because I am a perfectionist...but what can you do? I guess we all have our weaknesses.

One last insight from Marlin...and then I'm done for now...I promise. This insight was crazy, because it definitely directly applied to me. He compared vultures and hummingbirds. Do you know what my birdname was while I worked at New England Camp Cherith? Hummer. Short for Hummingbird. Here's what he had to say about the two birds. When a vulture is searching for food, all it sees is death and despair. It eats dead animals and leftovers from what other creatures left behind. When a vulture flies over a desert, it doesn't look for the good things; it looks for those which death has overtaken. But a hummingbird does just the opposite. A hummingbird looks for life in the bright, beautiful blooms of the cactus plants. The hummingbird looks for abundance despite the dryness of the desert. It flits from flower to flower, sustaining itself and the life of the cactus as it goes. Instead of bringing death, it brings life. I should be like a hummingbird. I should find the postive, bright spots in every situation, no matter how bleak it might appear. God is good, and He will provide, so why be stressed out? I have to remind myself of this every day. No matter how gray I might feel...a bright spot will come.

Anyway, thanks for reading...please keep me in your prayers as I venture to achieve this new outlook on life. Take care, all of you! *hug*

First of all, I want to wish all of you a very Happy, Healthy, Blessed New Year! Welcome to 2006! And I am definitely up way too late to be posting right now...don't believe blog time, I'm still figuring this thing out...I actually posted at 2:38 am...but oh well...BRACE YOURSELF...this may be a long post, and an attempt at being intellectual...;)

So, I'm awake because I just finished watching "Crash." What an AMAZING, THOUGHT PROVOKING movie. I had watched it before with my office mates, but we hadn't had time to talk through it. I watched it again tonight with my parents (or at least my mom...my dad left halfway through the movie...but that's a story for another time). I think I could watch that movie over and over again and still find valuable things in it. I have a different favorite scene each time! Here's the quote that opens the movie, spoken by Don Cheedle as Graham:

"It's the sense of touch. In any real city, you walk, you know? You brush past people, people bump into you. In L.A., nobody touches you. We're always behind this metal and glass. I think we miss that touch so much, that we crash into each other, just so we can feel something."

I love this quote. But the ironic thing is that what Cheedle's character is saying is pertinent to anywhere. The plot of this movie could take place from Pittsburgh, PA to New York City to LA to just about anywhere you want to go. We all put ourselves behind glass...we wall ourselves away from humanity in order to protect ourselves, our culture, our children, whatever. But in reality, all we are doing is hurting ourselves. When we don't take the time to get to know one another, to learn one another's stories, then we miss out. We fear people who are different from us, we become prejudiced, and we create reasons to fight. As the quote says, "...we crash into each other, just so we can feel something." So many people in this world are so afraid to love, afraid to listen, and afraid to care that they create stereotypes and prejudices to create a reason for conflict. Heck, feeling conflict, rage, anger, and hate is better than nothing, right? Another favorite scene of mine is when Sandra Bullock's character has fallen down the stairs and is embraced and cared for by her HISPANIC HOUSEKEEPER. Bullock's character comes to realize that just because someone doesn't speak English as well as she might like, may not make $80,000+ a year, or looks different from her, doesn't mean that they can't be friends. This particular character's "cultural bubble" is shattered when she realizes that her good friend of 10 years is a shallow bitch, and that that is probably what she has become as well. I love it. Overall, this is a very tenderhearted movie, despite the violence, anger, and swear words. There is so much value in the message...and I think the fact that it was even produced makes this world a little bit better of a place. But we have a long way to go. I don't know about you, but I'm going to commit to spending a little more time getting to know those around me whose culture might be a little different...instead of letting my fear paralyze me and shut me out.

On that note, I have another thing I've been pondering through the past day or two...I'm an oddball. Not that I didn't know this before, but I've realized in just the past 24 hours that I am not an oddball because of who I am. I am an oddball because of WHOSE I am. Sometimes I lament the fact that I met Christ and He has changed the way I think about things. It makes life ALOT more difficult sometimes! But nobody ever said that "taking up my cross and following Christ" would be easy. In fact, I think that Christ said Himself that we would be denied in our own hometowns and that we must leave the dead to bury the dead...and that we must leave our families behind. Such a hard concept to understand! Yet, in a way I understand sometimes. It is hard for me to go home to my parent's house. They don't think that my campus ministry job is a real job...I beg for my paycheck. I don't care too much about possessions...I don't care about how much money I make. Yes, I have a college degree, and no I may not be teaching. But that's okay. God has called me to a place where I belong. And it's hard for me to be here and around this bitterness...I am a strong believer in forgiveness, grace and love...and these people claim to be Christians as well...it's no wonder my dad wants nothing to do with church. Anyway, life has been interesting the past few days...I think that's about all I have to say on that note.

In short, a woman should consider exploring a relationship with a man who loves her a little bit more than she loves him. Then she should marry him when he asks her. Because he will.

Okay, that might be quite the statement. Maybe even a little bit controversial. But I've hashed it out with some friends and relatives of mine, and I'm sticking with it. Don't hear me wrong. I'm not saying a woman should marry a man she doesn't love. I'm suggesting that the man who might make a woman the happiest in the long run is the man who is devoted to her, cares about her well-being, puts her needs ahead of his own, wants no other woman but her, praises her to his friends and colleagues, esteems her value, realizes his life is richer, better, because she is in it. But that doesn't mean he won't mess up sometimes. He's upfront with you about where he is and what his feelings are. He's probably the 'good guy', not the thug, not the hustler, not the "bad boy" who sends our emotions reeling in a whirlwind of mountainous excitement. He's not the one we need to rescue. We will not be this man's savior.

We may be slow to recognize him at first because he doesn't send our emotions zooming like that other guy. We'll almost write him off, if we're not careful. But like I told my friend recently, all we have are our choices. That's all we have. We can make good ones or we can make bad ones. We can make choices based on our emotions alone, or we can make choices based on sound reasoning and good judgement. And as I spoke with my friend, I told her it wasn't just about the man who makes her feel good now. It's about choosing a man who will be committed to her in the long run. Who will be the best husband to her? Who will stand by her side if she is sick and cannot care for herself? Even with good choices, there are no guarantees, but it's still good to make them. We all take our chances. But if we are to struggle and suffer, it's better to struggle inside of the will of God than outside of it. Trust me. And think of it. It's not that we loved God first, but that He first loved us. And in response to His love for us, we love Him.
